Award.AwardTitle: Project Engage: Training Secondary Teachers to Deliver Computer Science and Engineering Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing computer science teachers who can support high school students in being successful in rigorous, academic computer science courses is a national need. Project Engage: Training Secondary Teachers to Deliver Computer Science and Engineering Instruction will support the implementation of an emerging Computer Science Principles course called Thriving in Our Digital World (TODW) in forty-five urban, suburban, and rural schools, including public, private, magnet, and charter schools, in Texas. The TODW course will be offered in a unique dual enrollment mode (concurrent high school and college credit). This project will test two innovative professional development techniques for expanding the reach to more schools: flipped classroom techniques, in which teachers receive recorded video-based professional development, and then use face-to-face time for more hands-on activities; and an automated system which will use artificial intelligence technology to support negotiation of common grades for student work between high school teachers and college faculty. This project's research agenda will address the following core challenge: In a field such as computer science where there is limited expertise, how can we most efficiently scale professional development so as many schoolteachers as possible can provide high quality instruction?

The STEM-C (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics, including Computing) Partnerships program supports research-driven partnerships between STEM experts and K-12 school systems to bring about institutional change for better STEM education at the K-12 level. This STEM-C Partnerships' Computer Science Education Expansion project builds on prior funding of the UTeachEngineering: Training Secondary Teachers to Deliver Design-Based Engineering Instruction Partnerships through the National Science Foundation's Math and Science Partnership program. This project will produce the scientific foundation and the concrete artifacts needed to deliver a highly scalable curriculum for TODW. The artifacts will include a differentiated curriculum, scalable professional development, and scalable assessment tools and processes. The differentiated curriculum will include formative assessments which can be used by teachers to architect novel pathways through the curriculum for individual students or whole classes. Assessments will be created that can be delivered through a double-blind collaborative review (DBCR) rubric scoring tool, which will include machine learning algorithms that help detect consistent discrepancies between scores of individual (novice) computer science teachers and (expert) college-level computer science professors. The DBCR tool will use machine learning techniques such as basic text features (Bag of Words), syntactic and semantic modeling (n-grams and Latent Dirichlet Allocation), and cluster analysis against existing artifact corpora. Since the assessments of student artifacts are explicitly tied to rubrics, human evaluators may also use the DBCR tool to specify specific features that support line item rubric scores. The available features will vary from project to project but will leverage a variety of tools available in the DBCR user interface: (1) selectable categorical classifications, (2) the highlighting of relevant text features, and (3) annotations to mark document structures, such as cross references and supporting evidence. Project evaluation will focus on both implementation fidelity of the TODW course and student-level outcomes in classes that implement TODW. If successful, the professional development could serve as a model for more scalable teacher professional development in many domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this award, we chose to focus on improving three aspects of the Thriving in our Digital World computer science that was previously-created with the assistance of the NSF: Teacher Training and Professional Development, Content Differentiation, and Student Assessment.

In terms of teacher training and professional development, we were able to realize the goal of creating a flipped learning environment for portions of the professional development that teachers need to undergo before being able to offer our course in a dual-enrollment setting.

Since most course materials are distributed through the Canvas Learning Management System, we created an extra course within the domain that was to be used as a teacher headquarters.  Here, teachers were able to access content modules that form a firm bedrock for understanding how computer science instruction is interwoven with computational thinking, problem-solving, and project-based learning.  Within this learning environment, future course instructors were able to differentiate the tasks that they performed based on their prior understanding of course underpinnings or based upon their desire for challenge and rigor.

These content modules also included assessments in the form of exams and small projects that the professional development facilitators on campus could then use to drive individualized instruction when the teachers came to campus for a two-week in-person professional development during the summer.

In keeping with the major goal of broadening interest in computer science coursework and offering a more granularized experience for students of differing experience levels, we have implemented a rigorous reworking of course materials to allow for differentiation.  First and foremost, every coding assignment in the course has had one to two optional paths that more advanced students can attempt in order to deepen their content knowledge.  As the course is primarily a CS Principles course at its core, the course material that was created prior to this project is already scaffolded in such a way as to present an engaging introductory experience to computer science.  By adding these differentiated assignments in the daily coursework, even students who had previously taken A.P. CS A (usually a course that would fall later in the coursework sequence) were sufficiently challenged and able to engage with material that expands their growth.

To further this aim, the main projects in the course were also differentiated to add an Honors Project component.  The Honors Project adds a significant step-up from the original project in terms of difficulty of content material, the necessity of outside research, and the ability to coordinate a successful project-based learning group.  

The work to differentiate the course continues, with new possible routes for students of varying interests and ability levels to traverse towards understanding of a common set of outcomes.

As of this time, the creation of a double-blind collaborative review (DBCR) rubric scoring tool to improve the reliability and scalability of our efforts is still underway.  However, in the interim, additional methods of assessment have been added to the course.  These include a series of student-driven project checkpoints wherein students self-assess according to project rubrics.  These checkpoints benchmark progress over time and serve as a major component of the project-based learning pedagogical methodology, facilitating both deeper understanding of the specific components of the tasks from a student point-of-view, but also helping foster productive teacher-to-student conversations as teachers transition to a new role: from content generator and provider to one of being a facilitator of student-driven knowledge creation and exploration.

Additionally, we implemented a badging system in order to communicate student progress in the course in an alternative way.  Usually, one measures success in a course by the grades that are earned on assignments, on exams, and on projects-- and to be sure, these are very important.  What these grades often don't measure, however, are the college and career readiness skills that are an essential component of becoming successful with college coursework.  The badges that students had the opportunity to earn throughout the year were awarded when students had achieved a high-level of competence in important skill areas.  This allowed both student and teacher to have alternate ways of measuring progress and success with college-level coursework.

There are 5 main skills that were assessed with this badging framework included Intellectual Curiosity, Problem Solving, Tenacity, Collaboration, and Time Management.
